material.mattext: The alternative hypothesis in this case is:
The proportion of smokers among US adults 25 or older who have a Bachelor's degree or higher is less than .22.
The proportion of smokers among US adults 25 or older who have a Bachelor's degree or higher is .22.
The proportion of smokers among US adults 25 or older who have a Bachelor's degree or higher is not .22.
There is a relationship between level of education level and smoking habits.

Good Job! Indeed, the alternative hypothesis usually represents what we want to check, or what we suspect is really going on. In this case what the researcher suspects that is going on is that the proportion of smokers among US adults (25+) who have a Bachelor's degree or higher is lower than the rate of all adults in this age group.

Incorrect. You chose the null hypothesis as the alternative hypothesis. Recall that the alternative hypothesis, Ha, usually represents what we (or in this case the researcher) want(s) to check, or what we (the researcher) suspect(s) is really going on.

Incorrect. While it is true that this claim could be an alternative hypothesis, it is not the alternative hypothesis in this case. What does the researcher suspects is really going on? Read the problem description carefully and try again.

Incorrect. While it is true that this claim could be an alternative hypothesis, it is not the alternative hypothesis in this case. In the context of this problem, the alternative hypothesis represents what the researcher suspects is really going on. Read the problem description carefully and try again.
